citation.article-title: Phaselicystis flava gen. nov., sp. nov., an arachidonic acid-containing soil myxobacterium, and the description of Phaselicystidaceae fam. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Phaselicystis flava sp. nov. Garcia, Reichenbach and Müller
Phaselicystis flava (fla′va. L. fem. adj. flava golden-yellow).
Displays all the characteristics of the genus.
In addition, vegetative cells are fat rods, 1.0–1.5×3.5–10.5 μm, and phase dark.
Swarms of tough and radial veins only on the surface of the agar, with flame-like peripheral extensions formed by migrating cells; shallow depressions evident in old cultures.

Fruiting bodies induced by microbial food bait, as golden-yellow, monolayered clusters on MCA spotted with E. coli and as sori (32–86×52–193 μm) of tightly packed sporangioles (20–49×25–56 μm) on VY/2 agar.
Myxospores are stout and short rods (1.0–1.2×3.2–4.0 μm), with rounded ends like vegetative cells; enclosed in thick, golden-yellow sporangial wall.
Cellulose and chitin are not degraded.
Good growth in sucrose, fructose, d-mannose and l-arabinose.
Resistant to aminoglycoside antibiotics gentamicin, apramycin, tobramycin and kanamycin and structurally related aminocyclitols spectinomycin and hygromycin B.
Sensitive to ampicillin, tetracycline and oxytetracycline.
Major cellular fatty acid components are iso-C15 : 0, C17 : 1 2-OH and C20 : 4.
The type strain is SBKo001T (=DSM 21295T =NCCB 100230T), isolated from a soil sample collected in the Philippines (Mt Makiling Forest Reserve, Laguna Province) in December 2006.
Strain NOSO-1 (=DSM 53757), isolated in July 1988 from a soil sample in Etosha Basin, Namibia (Spröer et al., 1999; Reichenbach et al., 2006), is a reference strain.
